margot 1.0.26

Format RATE results into readable tables, keeping raw model names

Source: R/margot_rate.R
margot_rate.Rd

Assemble two tables that summarise rank-average treatment effect (RATE) estimates from causal-forest models under two targeting operating characteristics (TOC): **AUTOC** and **Qini**. Each table retains the raw model names but maps them to human-readable outcome labels and appends 95% Wald confidence intervals.

Usage

margot_rate(
  models,
  label_mapping = NULL,
  remove_tx_prefix = TRUE,
  remove_z_suffix = TRUE,
  use_title_case = TRUE,
  remove_underscores = TRUE,
  round_digits = 3,
  highlight_significant = TRUE
)

Arguments

models

A list returned by `margot_multi_arm_causal_forest()` that contains an element `results`, itself a named list of model fits.

label_mapping

Named character vector mapping raw variable names to presentation labels.

remove_tx_prefix

Logical. Drop a leading `t0_` from variable names?

remove_z_suffix

Logical. Drop a trailing `_z` from variable names?

use_title_case

Logical. Convert labels to title case?

remove_underscores

Logical. Replace underscores with spaces?

round_digits

Integer. Decimal places to keep (default = 3).

highlight_significant

Logical. Bold labels whose 95 % CI is entirely above zero.

Value

A named list with two data frames

rate_autoc

Data frame with columns model, outcome, RATE Estimate, Std Error, 2.5%, 97.5%.

rate_qini

Identical structure, estimated with Qini weights.

Details

Outcome labels are created with `transform_var_name()`. Setting `highlight_significant = TRUE` wraps the outcome label in **bold** Markdown when the 95 % confidence interval lies strictly above zero, making it easy to emphasise robust results in Quarto or R Markdown documents.

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
rate <- margot_rate(my_models)
knitr::kable(rate$rate_autoc)
} # }
